page.title: Pronouns
page.introduction: Pronouns come in various types, including personal pronouns, possessives, reflexives, reciprocals, demonstrative pronouns, and indefinites. These pronouns normally stand alone in the place of a nominal phrase, but they can also be modified by a partitive phrase and in some languages may be modified by determiners and quantifiers. Some languages have both independent and dependent pronoun sets. Each of these types and issues will be looked at in turn.

radioGroup.prompt: You said that your language has classifiers which mark concord agreement throughout the nominal phrases. Do the pronouns that are written as separate words have classifiers attached to them?
radioGroup.radio: No, the pronouns are not marked with classifiers
Yes, the pronouns which are written as separate words are marked with classifiers as part of the concord agreement system

form.prompt: Since you have already detailed the forms of the classifiers, you only need to enter the roots for each of the pronouns here. However, if all the personal pronouns carry only a specific classifier (or just a couple of classifiers), you may choose to list the pronouns with the clasifier attached with a hyphen in the Pronouns section.

Since your language does not distinguish case, you should have only a single set of independent pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.

Since your language has a nominative-accusative case system, you should have distinct sets of independent pronouns that are normally used as subjects, objects, and possessors. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for verbs which have an Agent subject. Therefore, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for the objects of verbs which have an Agent subject. Therefore, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an Agent subject. Therefore, we will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of dative pronouns.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects.
Add the feature accusative.or.dative to all the pronouns that can occur as objects and indirect objects and Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the pronouns that occur as objects.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: accusative.or.dative, accusative.or.genitive, accusative.or.nominative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.nominative, nominative.or.genitive or -accusative (for all but accusative case), -dative, -genitive or -nominative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
form.prompt:
Since your language has an ergative-absolutive case system, you should have distinct sets of independent pronouns that can be used as subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. Since your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. Since your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for the objects of verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. Since your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of dative pronouns.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs or as objects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs or as objects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs or as objects of transitive verbs in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon:
Add the feature ergative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects of transitive verbs.
Add the feature absolutive.or.dative to all the pronouns that occur as objects or indirect objects of transitive verbs and as subjects of intransitive verbs.
Add the feature absolutive to all the pronouns that occur as objects of transitive verbs and as Agent subjects of intransitive verbs.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive
ergative
absolutive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: absolutive.or.dative, absolutive.or.ergative or ergative.or.dative.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: absolutive.or.dative, absolutive.or.genitive, absolutive.or.ergative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.ergative, ergative.or.genitive or -absolutive (for all but absolutive case), -dative, -genitive or -ergative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
form.prompt:
Since your language has a split case system, you should have distinct sets of independent pronouns that are normally used as subjects, objects, and possessors, plus some special sets which are used in the split ergativity cases. Since your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. Since your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject as for the objects of verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the normal object pronouns are also used for indirect objects and there is not an additional set of dative pronouns. Since your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an Agent subject, we will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of dative pronouns.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which normally appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which normally appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which normally appear as Agent subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which normally appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which normally appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which normally appear as objects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as possessors in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent first person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent second person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
Key the independent third person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.

Key the independent first person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.

Key the independent second person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.

Key the independent third person personal pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box, with each pronoun on a separate line.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects.
Add the feature accusative.or.dative to all the pronouns that can occur as objects and indirect objects and Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the pronouns that occur as objects.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: accusative.or.dative, accusative.or.genitive, accusative.or.nominative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.nominative, nominative.or.genitive or -accusative (for all but accusative case), -dative, -genitive or -nominative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
For the split ergativity cases, add the feature ergative to all the pronouns that can only occur as subjects of transitive verbs and add the feature absolutive to all the pronouns that can only occur as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. Note that if there is some overlap between the pronoun sets for nominative-accusative versus ergative-absolutive, you will probably need to have two entries in your lexicon for those pronouns, each marked with the appropriate case feature.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language also have sets of dependent pronouns?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there are dependent pronoun forms which attach to other words, as well as the independent pronouns

radioGroup.prompt: Where do the dependent pronouns attach to the verb or noun or other words?
radioGroup.radio: As proclitics or prefixes with some word categories and as enclitics or suffixes with other categories

radioGroup.prompt: Are the dependent pronouns the same as the classifiers for specific classes?
radioGroup.radio: No, the dependent pronouns are distinct from the classifiers
Yes, the dependent pronouns are either identical or closely related to the appropriate classifiers

form.prompt:
In the chart below, check any agreement features used on pronouns in your language. For class agreement, either a type or number should be used in the grammar output to replace the ## below.
person first first person, with no exclusive-inclusive distinction
first_exclusive first person, cannot include the hearer
first_inclusive first person, and including the hearer
second second person
third third person
number singular singular in number
dual two in number
plural plural in number
gender masculine male gender
feminine female gender
neuter neuter gender
animacy animate persons and animals
-animate inanimate objects
human humans
-human nonhumans
class class_## class number or type
form.instruction:
Add the relevant agreement features to each pronoun in the lexicon. If a pronoun is not specified for a particular type of agreement feature, do not add any feature of that type. For class agreement, please replace ## with a number up to 25 or the appropriate class type feature as detailed in
Overall Typology - Classifiers when keying the feature on an element in the lexicon.
